table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a nerve gas used by Klingons.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used for wielding or swinging an ax, a club, or the like.[1, p.64] It can also be applied to a {betleH:n}[2] or a whip[3].

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "be dry" in {TKD:src}, while {KGT:src} extends this with "be dried out".

table.name: mem
table.column: This sense of {QaD:v:2,nolink} comes from its similarity to {Qan:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also be used to refer to a software "bug".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: err, be mistaken, make a mistake

table.name: mem
table.column: Have the courage to admit your mistakes.

table.name: mem
table.column: This would be used in situations where the person needing help can't do whatever needs to be done without assistance, in contrast to {boQ:v}. The object of {QaH:v:nolink} can't carry out the task alone, so responsibility falls to the subject (or it is shared). There's nothing weak about asking for {QaH:v:nolink} when it is warranted, but an offer to {QaH:v:nolink} when {boQ:v:nolink} is expected may sometimes be mildly insulting.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: For help on using this program, see under {boQwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
A kradge has brown lips. The expression {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).[2]
Do not confuse this with the similarly named {qa'raj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: QamvIS Hegh qaq law' torvIS yIn qaq puS.
Better to die on our feet than live on our knees.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the title of the leader of the Klingon Empire, when it is not ruled by an Emperor.

table.name: mem
table.column: "To win" a competition is {Qap:v:nolink}. If the victory is decisive or particularly gratifying, the expression {Qapchu':v:nolink} is used, even if it's a bit redundant.[4]

This is defined in {TKD:src} as "work, function, succeed", and in {KGT:src} as "win" and "operate, be in operation" (two separate entries). The "succeed" and "win" meanings are elaborated upon in {TKW:src}. In {HQ 2.4:src}, it is explained that to Klingons, to win is to function perfectly.

▶ {tlhIngan 'IH qaD DaQap.:sen@@tlhIngan:n, 'IH:v, qaD:n, Da-:v, Qap:v:1} "Win Klingon beauty contest."[5] ▶ {qeylIS 'etlh Datlhapqa' 'e' DaQapbe'.:sen:nolink} "Fail to retrieve the Sword of Kahless."[5]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means that gravity is doing its job, whatever it is that gravity is supposed to do. That is, it expresses something like "that was supposed to happen".
This was the winning replacement proverb entry, submitted by Alan Anderson ({ghunchu'wI':n:name,nolink}), in the proverbs competition at {qep'a' 25 (2018):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the less common way to say this.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used as an exclamation indicating good wishes when someone is departing for a mission. See {Qapla'!:sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon version of this sentence has no exclamation mark as printed on {TKD p.171:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device around which thread or wire is wound.

table.name: mem
table.column: behave falsely honorably, behave in a falsely honorable manner

Deception is implied by the use of this verb. However, it differs from {toj:v} in that the deception involves honor or social status in some way. For example, this verb might be used of someone who claimed to be of a rank that he not had achieved, or to be a member of a house or family to which he did not belong.
behave falsely honourably, behave in a falsely honourable manner

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the verb (or adjective) meaning "to be good". Based on the examples, it's in the sense of having a desirable quality, rather than in the sense of not being evil (see {mIgh:v}).
For "good" as an exclamation expressing satisfaction, see {maj:excl}.
For describing enjoyable food or music, see {'ey:v} and {DuQ:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The meaning of this word is like {negh:n}, but it excludes officers ({yaS:n}). The highest ranks of {QaS:n:1h,nolink} are: ▶ {bu':n} "sergeant" ▶ {Da':n} "corporal"
It's possible that this word can be used to refer to a single troop member.[2, p.51]
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {tlhIngan QaS:n:nolink} is the unit of currency used in the game. From this game, we have the examples {"GO" DajuSDI' cha'vatlh QaS yItlhap:sen:nolink} and {wa'vatlh QaS yItlhap:sen:nolink}. Note that the singular prefix {yI-:v} is used even though {QaS:n:1h,nolink} is an inherently plural noun whose members are being counted.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: He appeared in the episode {TOS - Friday's Child:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: For "hard (not soft)", see {let:v}. See also {ngem Sarghmey tlha':sen:idiom} for an idiom related to difficulty or complexity.
This was defined as "be difficult" in {TKD:src} and as "be complex" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Unlike the English word "last", this means "final" and does not mean "previous" (which is {vorgh:v}) or "most recent" (which is {ret:v}).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is listed erroneously as a noun in {TKD:src} in both word lists, but is described as a verb on p.49. It is also used in {TKW:src} on p.211 as a verb.

table.name: mem
table.column: blow one's top, lose one's temper
See {Qay':v:2} for a related idiomatic expression.

In {TKD:src} this is defined as "blow one's top".[1] In {HQ 10.2:src}, the additional definition "lose one's temper" was added for clarification.[2]
"Cry".

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiomatic expression {'oy'qu' Qay'wI'wIj.:sen} This literally means "my little toe aches a lot", but it carries the idiomatic meaning "I'm extremely angry." The expression undoubtedly arose due to the homophony between {Qay':v:2,nolink} "use the little toe" and {Qay':v:1} "blow one's top".
And this little piggy cried "wee wee wee" all the way home.

table.name: mem
table.column: And this little piggy cried wee wee wee all the way home.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a physical puzzle, such as a jigsaw puzzle or metal hoops which need to be untangled. That is, such a puzzle must involves a physical object or objects which must be manipulated.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a piece of a jigsaw puzzle.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a bird, but it (specifically the {jajlo' Qa':n}) makes a particular ruckus at dawn.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Krada legs are a popular Klingon food made from the extremities of a krada.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of animal (similar to {Qa':n:1}, but smaller)

This word appears in the "Curses" section of the {KCD:src} Language Lab. In the introduction to the holodeck part of the game, it is used in a derogatory manner by Gowron to refer to the player character. Gowron says that there is no honour in killing a {Qa'Hom:n:nolink}, but that after the player has finished the holodeck adventure, they will no longer be as weak as a {Qa'Hom:n:nolink}, and then "it will be an honour to kill you".[2]
The English text in {KCD:src} for this word reads "little animal (e.g., Ligonian titmouse)", and it is accompanied by an image of a hedgehog. Presumably, whoever selected the image did not realise that a "titmouse" is a kind of bird, and not a kind of mouse (which a hedgehog also is not). The audio (which is spoken by Marc Okrand) addresses this discrepancy by implying that it resembles a titmouse only in its unimportance: "The translation 'titmouse' is really only an approximation of what this word means. A {Qa'Hom:n:nolink} is a small animal considered rather insignificant."
This error is alluded to again in {HQ 10.4:src}, which states some people have confused it with a bird for reasons unknown to Maltz. In a personal message to {Quvar:n:name} in May 2021, Marc Okrand confirmed that the image is correct and that the text is in error, i.e., the {Qa'Hom:n:nolink} resembles a Terran hedgehog.
Even though {KCD:src} was published before {KGT:src}, the book is listed as the first source since it is where the definition comes from.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the author of {qul naj:n}, who also wrote a commentary on {qeS'a':n}. He is the son of M'Lind (see {mI'lInnID:n:name}).
[1] {TNG - The Measure of a Man:src}, [2] {VOY - Author, Author:src}, [3] {The Klingon Art of War:src}, [4] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2014:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can also be used for other kinds of (similar) jewelry, like for a toe (though it would probably be {yaD Qeb:n@@yaD:n:1, Qeb:n:1}, or more specific, like {Qay'wI' Qeb:n@@Qay'wI':n, Qeb:n:1}). This is not used for a link in a chain, unless the chain is made up of (jewelry-like) rings.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The acronym STEM stands for Science ({QeD:n}), Technology ({cham:n}), Engineering ({jonta':n}), and Mathematics ({mI'QeD:n}).

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This appears as {QeD patmey noch patmey je:n:nolink} "science and remote sensing systems".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Qo'noS romuluS je boSuqlaH. vabDot tera' Qejbogh DIvI' ram boSuqlaH.:sen:nolink} "Kronos, Romulus and even the puny Federation's precious Earth, are all up for grabs."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the general word for a "doctor" or "physician". A doctor who performs surgery is a {HaqwI':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not limited to weapons. For example, it can be used for putting a tool into a tool belt.

"Cram".
This word was awarded to {janSIy:n:name,nolink} as a Friend of Maltz.

table.name: mem
table.column: hole (like a hole in the ground)

This can be used for a hole in the ground, a hollow in a tree, and so on. The difference between a {QemjIq:n:nolink} and a {qung:n} is that the former can be filled ({teb:v}).[1] (That is, a {QemjIq:n:nolink} is a cavity or depression, while a {qung:n:nolink} is a puncture or perforation.)
In the Beatles song "A Day in The Life", a line goes "Four thousand holes in Blackburn, Lancashire".

table.name: mem
table.column: ground-up, dried-up mixture for brewing tea
This refers to the dried tea brew including plants or animal parts. For the drink made from this, see {Dargh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object, if there is one, is the thing that the subject is anxious about.[1]
The original request was for "worry (about something)".

table.name: mem
table.column: Both this and {ruq:v} can be used for gas that comes up from your gut and out of your mouth and also for gas that does down from your gut and out the other way. To distinguish between gases emitted from different orifices, use a phrase involving {nuj:n}, {Hugh:n}, or {Sa'Hut:n:1}.[2]

It sounds like "decrepit".
This seems to be made up of {Qep:v} "be anxious" and {'It:v} "be depressed", but this is probably a coincidence as the words were revealed many years apart.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the projectile or weapon, and the target is marked with {-Daq:n:suff} (see {bach:v} for details).
This verb is also used to express the idea of "face" (orient towards) (see {Qeq:v:2}).
This was defined as "aim" in {KGT:src} and clarified to "aim (at)" at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just an application of {Qeq:v:1}. The object is the one oriented toward someone or something, and the thing or person being faced is marked with {-Daq:n:suff}. With this meaning, this verb is often used with {-'egh:v:suff} or {-chuq:v:suff}.[1]
It's unclear how this would be used with {-chuq:v:nolink}. Dr. Okrand said he would clarify this at a later time.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to heat meat in animal's blood and condiments.

table.name: mem
table.column: The song "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!" by The Beatles is about the circus performer (and tightrope walker) William Kite, who is referred to as "Mr. K".

table.name: mem
table.column: The temperature words really are about temperature and not about effect or perception, so that clothing, for example, is not said to be "hot" or "cold" in Klingon (but the person wearing it is).[2]
The clarification about clothing was made during the Q & A session at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a show performed at a {much Qe':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
To say that a bridge spans something (a river, a valley, and so on), use {vech:v}.
The word for the command deck of a ship (also called a "bridge" in English) is {meH:n}.
This is a reference to the novel "The Bridge over the River Kwai" ("Le Pont de la Rivière Kwai") by Pierre Boulle.

table.name: mem
table.column: To express casting/throwing/making a shadow, {QIb:n:nolink} could be used as the subject of {nIS:v}. The object, if specified, would be the surface onto which the shadow is cast.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: That the object is what's filtered was clarified during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the phenomenon of speech. For speech sounds, see {QIch wab:n}. For pronunciation, see {QIch wab Ho'DoS:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: An individual speech sound is {QIch wab:n:nolink}. Speech sounds collectively are {QIch wabmey:n@@QIch wab:n, -mey:n}.
This was defined as "speech sound" in {KLI mailing list 2018.02.17:src} and defined again as "phoneme" at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
To fully understand the sounds of Klingon, it is recommended that you purchase {The Klingon Dictionary:src}, which has a fuller description of the sounds, as well as the audio recordings {Conversational Klingon:src} and {Power Klingon:src}, in which you can hear them spoken.[1; 2; 3]
The transcription system used to write Klingon in the Roman (English) alphabet is phonetic, meaning that words are written exactly as they are pronounced. In the following description of the sounds of Klingon, which is intended only as a rough guide, IPA phonetic symbols are shown between a pair of slashes following the Roman letter or letters used to transcribe each sound.
The consonants {b:sen:nolink} /b/, {ch:sen:nolink} /ʧ/, {j:sen:nolink} /d͡ʒ/, {l:sen:nolink} /l/, {m:sen:nolink} /m/, {n:sen:nolink} /n/, {p:sen:nolink} /pʰ/, {t:sen:nolink} /tʰ/, {v:sen:nolink} /v/, {w:sen:nolink} /w/, and {y:sen:nolink} /j/ are pronounced more or less as in American English.
{D:sen:nolink} /ɖ/ and {S:sen:nolink} /ʂ/ are retroflex, that is, they are pronounced with the tongue touching the roof of the mouth.
{gh:sen:nolink} /ɣ/ is similar to {H:sen:nolink} (see below), but voiced. It sounds somewhat like gargling.
{H:sen:nolink} /x/ is like the "ch" in the Scottish word "loch" or the name of the German composer "Bach".
{ng:sen:nolink} /ŋ/ is the same sound as is found at the end of the English words "sing" or "thing", but in Klingon it can come at the beginning of words.
{q:sen:nolink} /qʰ/ is like the English "k", but with the tongue reaching for or touching the uvula. It sounds a little bit like you're choking.
{Q:sen:nolink} /q͡χ/ is similar to a combination of {q:sen:nolink} and {H:sen:nolink}, and sounds like you're really choking and trying to dislodge food stuck in your throat.
The Klingon {r:sen:nolink} /r/ is slightly trilled or rolled.
{tlh:sen:nolink} /t͡ɬ/ is found in some Native American languages, and is produced by putting your tongue in the position to say {t:sen:nolink}, then forcing air through the sides of your mouth as if to say {l:sen:nolink}.
The glottal stop {':sen:nolink} /ʔ/ ({qaghwI':n:nolink}) is a slight pause or catch in the throat, like between the two syllables of "uh-oh".
The vowel {a:sen:nolink} /ɑ/ sounds like the "a" in "psalm" or "father".
The vowel {e:sen:nolink} /ɛ/ sounds like the "e" in "bed" or "egg".
The vowel {I:sen:nolink} /ɪ/ sounds like the "i" in "bit" or "misfit". Note that it is always written as a capital letter.
The vowel {o:sen:nolink} /o/ sounds like the "o" in "note" or "mosaic".
The vowel {u:sen:nolink} /u/ sounds like the "u" in "prune" or "food".
The diphthongs {aw:sen:nolink}, {ew:sen:nolink}, {Iw:sen:nolink}, {ay:sen:nolink}, {ey:sen:nolink}, {Iy:sen:nolink}, {oy:sen:nolink}, and {uy:sen:nolink} are possible, and sound essentially like their components. Note that {ay:sen:nolink} rhymes with English "why" or "my", whereas {ey:sen:nolink} rhymes with "way" or "may".
The names of the Klingon consonants consist of the sound followed by {ay:sen:nolink}, and the names of the vowels consist of the sound preceded by {':sen:nolink} and followed by {t:sen:nolink}. The glottal stop is an exception, being called the {qaghwI':n}.[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: A "regional accent" would be {Sep QIch wab Ho'DoS:n:nolink} or {Sep QIch wab Sar:n:nolink} or {Sep QIch wab Ho'DoS Sar:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a hand-held device, pressed up against an adversary.
This word appears to contain {pej:v}, but that might just be a coincidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of this verb is that which is explained, and the person to whom the explanation is given is the indirect object.[2]
▶ {yaSvaD nab QIj:sen@@yaS:n, -vaD:n, nab:n, QIj:v} "He/she explains the plan to the officer"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used when there's no way out, or there's nothing to lose. It includes ideas like "last-ditch, do-or-die, hopeless, doomed".[1]
This word is not used to mean "eager for, longing for, in real need of, having a great desire for", and so on. To express those ideas, one might use {-nIS:v} with {-qu':v}, or perhaps {neHqu':sen@@neH:v, -qu':v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can take {watrIn:n} or {'onroS:n} as its object.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is often used to refer to email messages among Klingonists.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word also refers to the sharpened end of a pencil. It likely refers to the sharp end of any stick-like object.[2]
It is used to refer to the point on a (geometric) star ({DujtlhuQ:n}).[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: plain spearhead with single sharp point

table.name: mem
table.column: It may have any number of points, not just five.

table.name: mem
table.column: In some early versions of {TNK:src}, "postcard" was translated as {ngeHmeH QIn nav:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Also spelled "Krencha", this is a reptilian animal native to {Qo'noS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is similar to a {ghIntaq:n:1}, except that the handle is longer, the blade is much wider, and a downward-curved horn protrudes from the bottom of the blade. It is rarely used today.[1]

This appears to have been the result of using Bing translator to translate "spear with horn", without understanding that {gheb:n:nolink} means "horn" as in the musical instrument, rather than a hooked point as in a weapon. This word was retroactively "vetted" by Marc Okrand after the book's publication.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not limited to weapons. For example, it can be used for removing a tool from a tool belt.

"Quick". In gun duels, the winner is often the one with the faster draw. Also, "quick" has an archaic sense of "the living", as in "the quick and the dead".
This word was awarded to {janSIy:n:name,nolink} as a Friend of Maltz.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being sewn or stitched together.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "kris" or "keris" is a type of wavy-bladed knife found in Southeast Asia.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the name of a Terran holiday.
There is no traditional Klingon way to say something like "Merry Christmas". An expression such as {wornagh yItlhutlh!} might be more appropriate.[1]
Maltz thought "Merry Christmas" and "Happy New Year" were silly things to say.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a volcano ({qulHuD:n}) on {Qo'noS:n}, where legend says {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} dipped a lock of his hair to forge the first {betleH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any military organization. The official Klingon {QI':n} is the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {PK:src}, this is pronounced by Michael Dorn like {Qetlop:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of an outpost in the Klingon Empire near the Romulan border, where an important peace agreement was signed with the Federation.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Paradise (source of creation in Klingon mythology)

There are two idioms associated with {QI'tu':n:nolink}, both to do with its age: {ngo'; QI'tu' rur@@ngo':v, QI'tu':n, rur:v} and {qan; QI'tu' rur@@qan:v:1, QI'tu':n, rur:v}. The first might be applied to an object or idea which is very old, while the second would be applied to an old person.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is only noted as a curse in {TKD:src}. The explanation that it is a vulgar expression which defies translation comes from {KCD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Klingon Empire, at one point colonized by Klingons.
It may or may not be a coincidence that the name of this planet appears to be made up of {QI':n} and {yoS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix {-meH:v} and the verb {chIw:v} are used with this to express having a tendency to do something.
The typical way to use this was clarified during the Q & A session. MO said he would avoid the verb {ghaj:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It says on {TKD p.50:src} that a verb expressing a state or quality can be used "immediately following a noun". The {paq'batlh:src} excerpt is an example of two adjectives on a noun ("long and dangerous battle"), where one of the Klingon verbs uses {-bogh:v:suff}, which suggests two verbs used adjectivally cannot follow one noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {nIteb Qob qaD jup 'e' chaw'be' SuvwI'.:sen} ▶ {Qob lIb bam SoH chuDlI' je.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column:
Disagreement is also expressed by the idiomatic expression {cha' DoSmey DIqIp.:sen:idiom}
This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
At {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}, MO accepted {maQoch 'e' wIQochbe':sen:nolink} as a way of expressing "we agree to disagree" in Klingon, though he did not compose the sentence.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This animal is kept as a pet.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the organ. For the sense of "mind", see {yab:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is like what a pig does, but it's not restricted to pigs or targs.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to touch one's fingers gently on something, usually a few times.
A person's shoulder was given as an example of a possible object for this verb.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb refers to the idea of war. For concrete fighting, see {ghob:v}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: be hazardous, be perilous, be treacherous
Despite its definition, the way this verb is used grammatically is based on its literal sense, and it is ungrammatically to use this adjectivally.[1, p.163]

▶ {Qom Qu':sen:nolink} "The mission is perilous."[1, p.161] ▶ {Qom He:sen:nolink} "The route is treacherous."[1, p.161] ▶ {Qompu' Duj:sen:nolink} "The ship is hazardous, has been left in a hazardous condition."[1, p.163]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Chronos" (Greek for "time"), from which comes the word "chronicle".

table.name: mem
table.column: {Qong:v:nolink} is used in {TKD:src} to illustrate the pronominal prefixes with no object. While the text strongly suggests that it does not take an object, it isn't explicitly stated.

table.name: mem
table.column: put to sleep, cause to sleep
This is also used for extinguishing fires (see {qul:n}).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word may be evidence that at an earlier stage of the language, there may have been a noun {Qong:n:nolink} meaning "sleep" or a verb suffix {-Daq:v:suff,nolink} meaning "place where one does something", or that a noun {Qong:n:nolink} current exists which is unattested elsewhere, but these are just conjectures.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons do not lie in bed.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz said that this means "bed pouch", and perhaps a sleeping bag is {QongDaq buq'a':n:nolink} and a pillow is {QongDaq buqHom:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a very non-Klingon concept.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is usually applied to old weapons, tools, mechanical devices, and so on.[2, p.163]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used only in reference to food expected to be eaten live, such as {qagh:n}.[1, p.163]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Music is said by Klingons to {jaqmoH:v}, {SeymoH:v}, {tungHa':v}, or {pIlmoH:v}.[1]
This refers to any music, whether vocal or instrumental or both.[2]
This sounds like the Cantonese word for "song" (曲).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a more general term for a group (of any size) playing music, compared to {ghenraq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This may be shortened to just {jan:n:2} if the context is clearly musical, but this is seldom done.[1]
Types of Klingon musical instruments include: percussion ({'In:n}), wind (no overall term), windbag or bellows ({SuSDeq:n}), and stringed ({HurDagh:n} and {ngItHel:n}). Wind instruments include the {Dov'agh:n}, the {gheb:n}, and the {meSchuS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v:nolink}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.
This verb might be appropriate if Klingons engaged in shadowboxing.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The hunter does not lie down with the prey.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a leader who conquered neighbouring areas of his region.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This region is named after Krotmag ({Qotmagh:n:name}).
In the Krotmag region, speakers replace {b:sen:nolink} with {m:sen:nolink} and {D:sen:nolink} with {N:sen:nolink}.[1, p.21]
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: Be careful not to say this word by accident if you mean {Hotlh:v:2} instead.[2]
▶ {QaptaHvIS So'wI', Hoch jagh Dujmey DaQotlh.:sen:nolink} "Disable all enemy ships while cloaked."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "hear" and not just "listen". The hearer must actually perceive and understand what is being said.[2, p.31]
This is defined only as "hear" in {TKD:src}. The "listen to" definition was added based on the explanation in {TKW:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
This word does not appear in the word lists in {TKD:src}, but appears in the explanation of {-moH:v:suff} in {TKD 4.2.4:src}, where {chenmoH:v} also appears. This entry is here for ease of reference.

table.name: mem
table.column: The actors who performed this song on {KCD:src} mispronounced the intended {Say'moHchu':v:nolink} as {SeymoHchu':v:nolink}. This error has since propagated to other recordings of the song.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This can be used for a certificate or a diploma, but not for a license or a permit, which would be a {chaw':n}. The difference is that a {Qoyje':n:nolink} is proof or verification of some sort of achievement or accomplishment, but it doesn't necessarily allow you to do anything as a result of that.
Klingons consider title deeds ({yer ghajwI' chaw':n}) to be a type of {chaw':n:nolink}, rather than a type of {Qoyje':n:nolink}, since property ownership is granted by a government or other authority, but isn't an accomplishment.
Pun: {Qoy:v} "hear" + {je':v:1} "buy" = "hereby". Many certificates begin with "I hereby certify that...".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used when the liquid slops over or out of whatever container it was in.

table.name: mem
table.column: no, I won't, I refuse, I disagree
{TKD:src} lists this as "no, I won't, I refuse", and {TKDA:src} adds "no, I disagree".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the Klingon Homeworld.

▶ {tlhIngan wo' yuQmey chovlu'chugh Qo'noS potlh law' Hoch potlh puS. roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH. pa' 'oHtaH vaS'a''e'. tlhIngan qum waw' 'oH. yoq yIn yuQ 'oH Qo'noS'e'. yInSIp voQSIp je ngaS muDDaj.:sen:nolink} "The principal planet of the Klingon Empire, Qo'noS is usually referred to as simply "The Homeworld." This is where the Klingon Great Hall is located, the center of the Klingon government. Qo'noS is a class-M planet with an oxygen/nitrogen atmosphere."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
The slang meaning of {chong:v:2,slang}, when applied to a person, is equivalent to {Qubchu'} "think clearly".[3]

In {msn 1996.12.12:src}, Dr. Okrand responded to a sentence someone else wrote. In his response, he affirmed that the sentence fragment {... 'e' DaQub'a'?:sen:nolink} was the correct way to say "Do you think that...?"
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vIQub.:sen:nolink} "I think that you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the English idiom "(have a) happy holiday" (where "holiday" may be substituted for the actual name of a holiday) does not make sense when literally translated into Klingon. To translate such an expression, consider using {tIv:v} instead. (See {qoSlIj DatIvjaj!:sen} for an example.)

table.name: mem
table.column: Regional words for forehead include: {boD:n}, {jargh:n}, {mIQ:n}, {'aQlo':n}, {Huy'Dung:n}, {tuqvol:n}, and {no''och:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not mean exactly the same thing as {'IQ:v}, since it implies a change from being happy to not being happy.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word and {lot:n:nolink} are mostly interchangeable. To refer to something that in all likelihood one can't recover from (like the loss of {pIraqSIS:n}), {lot:n:nolink} is better.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The difference between this and {reH:v} is that this refers to structured play, whereas {reH:v:nolink} refers to unstructured play. This verb does not take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", cricket (the sport) is translated as {ghew:n:nolink}. Specifically, "Cricket, please." was translated as {DaH ghew yIQuj.:sen:nolink}[3]
[1] {TKD:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}, [3] {Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word means "ball" in the sense of a spherical object for playing.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {QujwI' lIw:n:nolink} is used to refer to the game pieces that stand in for the player.
In the example, {polmeH QujwI' lIw:n:nolink} is not a fixed construction, even though the English translation is "collectible tokens". A more literal translation would be "six tokens to collect".[2]
▶ {polmeH jav QujwI' lIwmey:sen@@pol:v, -meH:v, jav:n:1, QujwI' lIw:n, -mey:n} "6 Collectible Tokens"

table.name: mem
table.column: Outside of compounds such as {QumpIn:n}, {Qum:sen:nolink} is found only as a verb. This suggests that a noun {Qum:n:archaic} existed at some time in the past.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The existence of {Qum:sen:nolink} as a noun in the past is attested to by words such as {QumpIn:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The first part of this word, {Qum:sen:nolink}, is found elsewhere only as a verb. This suggests that a noun {Qum:n:archaic} existed in the past.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: {Sam:v} is probably better for this sense of "find" than {tu':v}, but that's how the sentence appears on {TKD p.171:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for a scroll which is implied to be important, sacred, or ancient (though it is not necessarily all three). Any {Qumran:n:nolink} is a {tetlh:n}, but not every {tetlh:n:nolink} is a {Qumran:n:nolink}. When a scroll is used in a ceremony, it is typically referred to as a {Qumran:n:nolink}.[2]
This is a reference to the archaeological site where the Dead Sea Scrolls were discovered.

table.name: mem
table.column: Little is known about the Klingon gods, except that it seems they acted collectively, and no single individual stood out from among them. {Qun'a':n:nolink} may or may not be an appropriate translation for the supreme deity of a monotheistic religion, since the {Qun'a':n:nolink} would still be one among many.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: For example, this might refer to the corner of a table which is not a sharp angle.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {jIH Qup law' SoH Qup puS:sen:nolink} "I'm younger than you."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not mean a building ({qach:n}) or a collection of people or states ({DIvI':n}, {tlham:n:2}), but rather the way things fit together or the arrangement of the parts of something bigger. It can be used to mean "anatomy" when referring to animals.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can only refer to physically supporting something. It cannot be used for psychological or any other non-physical type of support. The word {ghaq:v} is used for monetary support.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: May your coordinates be free of tribbles!

table.name: mem
table.column: Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchugh, qoj matlhHa'chugh, pagh ghaH SuvwI''e'.
If a warrior ignores duty, acts dishonorably, or is disloyal, he is nothing.
If a warrior ignores duty, acts dishonourably, or is disloyal, he is nothing.

table.name: mem
table.column: When you begin a mission, remember Aktuh and Melota.

table.name: mem
table.column: There are three shifts on a Klingon ship: ▶ {Qu' poH wa'DIch:n:nolink} "duty shift" ▶ {Qu' poH cha'DIch:n:nolink} "leisure shift" ▶ {Qu' poH wejDIch:n:nolink} "sleep shift"

table.name: mem
table.column: Qu'Daj ta'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.
To die in the line of duty is the hope of every Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingon curse, said in moments of extreme anger

This is only noted as a curse in {TKD:src}. The explanation that this is something one might say in moments of extreme anger comes from {CK:src}.
In a deleted scene from {Star Trek V:src}, the response to this curse was an invective in Klingon followed by the English "Screw you too!"
